user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_thread_name_:
```c
static int
MHD_set_thread_name_ (const MHD_thread_ID_native_ thread_id,
                      const char *thread_name)
{
  if (NULL == thread_name)
    return 0;

#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU)
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SET_NAME_NP_FREEBSD)
  /* FreeBSD and OpenBSD use different function name and void return type */
  pthread_set_name_np (thread_id, thread_name);
  return ! 0;
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
  /* NetBSD use 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
   *                         third argument is a single argument for printf();
   * OSF1 use 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
   * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both form are used in same way.
   */
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name, 0);
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The initial NULL check (if (NULL == thread_name) return 0;) is a reachable early-exit and does not indicate unreachable code. Each return inside the conditional compilation branches is reachable when the corresponding macro is defined, and comments are not executable code. The primary concerns to investigate for Rule 2.1 are: (1) the entire #if/#elif/#elif block because different build configurations will include only one branch — the excluded branches are not part of that build (preprocessor exclusion is not a runtime unreachable-code issue, but any branch that is never selected by any build configuration should be checked across the project), and (2) the absence of a fallback (#else) branch: if none of the HAVE_PTHREAD_* macros is defined the function will fall off the end without a return value (the code after the #endif, i.e. the function closing brace), which is a problematic code path and must be investigated. Other lines in the function are either reachable, conditional on configuration, or non-executable (comments), so they do not need further investigation for unreachable-code concerns.
